subject: Member Drive
msgSnippet: Hello all Read_Alphabet Members: The Read_Alphabet group stands at 307 members today, a number never before attained to my knowledge.  I would like to see our
messageBody:
Hello all Read_Alphabet Members:

The Read_Alphabet group stands at 307 members today, a number never
before attained to my knowledge. I would like to see our membership
continue to expand. In fact, I would like to see it expand even more
rapidly. The more people who are introduced to QS and begin using it,
the more likely we are to reach a point where friends start to tell
friends about this great "new" way to write English.

If each one of us, convinced just one person in the next month to try a
membership in the group -- after all, it's free -- we could expand to
600 members in short order.

I would challenge you to bring the subject up with people you know who
are curious about the world and and not afraid to be innovative. Send
me the names and e-mails of those who are willing to try a free, no
strings attached membership. After all, what have they got to lose? I
will send them an invitation. All they have to do is click on it to
accept. If the task of sending out invitations becomes too onerous, we
can always appoint new moderators to take over some of the load.

To see who in our group is willing to commit to mention QS to someone
they know, perhaps, a student, a professional person, or a young person
who would like to learn a "code" that no one else can read, please
respond to the new poll which will be e-mailed to you right after this
message. You just click "Yes" I'm willing to try it or "No thanks."
This will give us an idea how many members are willing to give it a shot
in the next month. I am curious to see what kind of results we would
get if we made a modest effort to get the word out to those we all know
who could really benefit from QS. Come to think of it -- that is almost
everybody we know, isn't it!

Thanks.

Paige Gabhart

P.S. I have convinced two new people to join in the last month. It is
really not that hard.

Hello all Read_Alphabet Members:

The Read_Alphabet group stands at 307 members today, a number never 
before attained to my knowledge.  I would like to see our membership 
continue to expand.  In fact, I would like to see it expand even more 
rapidly.  The more people who are introduced to QS and begin using it, 
the more likely we are to reach a point where friends start to tell 
friends about this great "new" way to write English.

If each one of us, convinced just one person in the next month to try a 
membership in the group -- after all, it's free -- we could expand to 
600 members in short order.

I would challenge you to bring the subject up with people you know who 
are curious about the world and and not afraid to be innovative.  Send 
me the names and e-mails of those who are willing to try a free, no 
strings attached membership.  After all, what have they got to lose? I 
will send them an invitation.  All they have to do is click on it to 
accept.  If the task of sending out invitations becomes too onerous, we 
can always appoint new moderators to take over some of the load.

To see who in our group is willing to commit to mention QS to someone 
they know, perhaps, a student, a professional person, or a young person 
who would like to learn a "code" that no one else can read, please 
respond to the new poll which will be e-mailed to you right after this 
message.  You just click "Yes" I'm willing to try it or "No thanks."   
This will give us an idea how many members are willing to give it a shot 
in the next month.  I am curious to see what kind of results we would 
get if we made a modest effort to get the word out to those we all know 
who could really benefit from QS.  Come to think of it -- that is almost 
everybody we know, isn't it!

Thanks.

Paige Gabhart

P.S. I have convinced two new people to join in the last month.  It is 
really not that hard.
